abstract.para: This document explains how to assess, measure and enforce security baselines with the help of &openscap;.

sect1.title: What is &openscap;?
sect1.para: &openscap; is a collection of open source tools that implement the Security Content Automation Protocol (SCAP) maintained by the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST). &openscap; supports automated configuration, vulnerability and patch checking, technical control compliance activities, and security measurement.

sect1.title: Benefits
sect1.para: The &openscap; tools, together with the Scap Security Guide, can be used for auditing your system in an automated way. The SCAP Security Guide implements security guidances recommended by respected authorities. These security guidances are transformed into a machine readable format which then can be used by &openscap;.

sect1.title: SCAP Security Guide
sect1.para: &suse; ships the Scap Security Guide toolset in the scap-security-guide RPM package. After you have installed the package, find XML files for all SCAP components described in in /usr/share/xml/scap/ssg/content/. They are named according to the SCAP component and to the &sle; codestream they apply to (code 12 or 15). The directory also holds XML files specific to &osuse;.
The DataStream (DS) XML files are very useful because they include everything you will need when you want to harden and audit your &sle; system.

sect1.title: SCAP Components and their interaction
sect1.para: SCAP consists of the following components which interact with each other.

listitem.para: An XML format developed and moderated by the Center for Internet Security (CIS). It represents system information and reports results. It supports platform-dependent and -independent tests. Every OVAL XML file includes oval definitions related to a set of tests which are described by objects, states and variables.

An XML format developed by NIST. SCAP uses it for automated compliance checking and scoring. It specifies security checklists, benchmarks and configuration documentation. The XCCDF XML file includes a benchmark as a set of different profiles related to different groups. Each group is a set of rules which have OVAL definitions. Each profile is related to different good practices such as DISA STIG, HIPAA, PCI-DSS, or ANSSI.
An XML format maintained by NIST and NDV. It uses a standardized naming scheme for IT products with the following elements: cpe:/part:vendor:product:version:update:edition:language
An XML format which packs different SCAP components (CPE, XCCDF, OVAL) into a single file. It can be used to distribute SCAP content over the network.
